stem: ABG: pH 7.25, PaCO2 58 mm Hg, HCO3- 25 mEq/L. What is the primary disorder?
rationale_correct: Low pH with elevated PaCO2 and near-normal HCO3- indicates acute respiratory acidosis without significant renal compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct acute pattern. | B: Chronic would show elevated HCO3-. | C: HCO3- not low. | D: No second primary acidifying process.
keywords_to_notice: low pH | high PaCO2 | normal HCO3-
common_trap: Calling it chronic due to high CO2.

stem: ABG: pH 7.44, PaCO2 30 mm Hg, HCO3- 20 mEq/L. What best describes this pattern?
rationale_correct: Low PaCO2 with decreased HCO3- and near-normal pH indicates chronic respiratory alkalosis with renal compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because compensation lowers bicarbonate. | B: Acute would have normal HCO3-. | C: pH not acidemic. | D: Values move in compensatory direction.
keywords_to_notice: near normal pH | low PaCO2 | low HCO3-
exam_logic: Look at pH direction first, then compensation.

stem: ABG: pH 7.31, PaCO2 34 mm Hg, HCO3- 17 mEq/L. Expected PaCO2 by Winter formula is approximately 1.5(17)+8=33.5. What does this indicate?
rationale_correct: Measured PaCO2 (34) closely matches expected (≈34), indicating appropriate compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct compensation alignment. | B: PaCO2 not elevated above expected. | C: PaCO2 not below expected. | D: Chronicity not indicated here.
exam_logic: Use formula to confirm compensation adequacy.

stem: ABG: pH 7.56, PaCO2 48 mm Hg, HCO3- 42 mEq/L. What is the primary disorder?
rationale_correct: High pH with markedly elevated bicarbonate indicates primary metabolic alkalosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because HCO3- elevated significantly. | B: PaCO2 not low. | C: No second alkalotic driver. | D: HCO3- elevated not compensatory pattern.
common_trap: Mistaking compensatory CO2 retention as primary disorder.
exam_logic: Match pH direction with primary variable.

stem: ABG: pH 7.28, PaCO2 32 mm Hg, HCO3- 15 mEq/L. Chemistry: Na 140, Cl 102. What is the anion gap?
rationale_correct: AG = 140 − (102+15)=23, elevated indicating high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct calculation. | B-D: Incorrect arithmetic.
keywords_to_notice: calculate AG | Na minus Cl plus HCO3-

stem: Lab values: Na 136, Cl 110, HCO3- 18. What is most accurate?
rationale_correct: AG = 136 − (110+18)=8, which is normal; low HCO3- indicates non-gap metabolic acidosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct interpretation. | B: Gap not elevated. | C-D: Not supported.
common_trap: Assuming all acidosis is high gap.

stem: ABG: pH 7.18, PaCO2 38 mm Hg, HCO3- 14 mEq/L. What is the first classification step?
rationale_correct: pH below 7.35 indicates acidemia regardless of cause.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct initial classification. | B-D: pH clearly acidemic.
exam_logic: Always classify pH before determining cause.

stem: ABG: pH 7.60, PaCO2 25 mm Hg, HCO3- 30 mEq/L. What is most accurate?
rationale_correct: Both PaCO2 and HCO3- are alkalotic drivers, indicating two primary alkalosing processes.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because both variables raise pH. | B-D: Each describes single disorder.
keywords_to_notice: very high pH | low CO2 | high HCO3-
common_trap: Calling one primary and one compensatory when both worsen pH.
exam_logic: If both variables push pH same direction, think mixed.

stem: ABG: pH 7.48, PaCO2 50 mm Hg, HCO3- 36 mEq/L. What is most accurate?
rationale_correct: Elevated HCO3- with alkalemic pH and elevated PaCO2 indicates compensatory hypoventilation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct compensation pattern. | B: HCO3- too high for chronic alone. | C-D: Not supported.

stem: ABG: pH 7.37, PaCO2 39 mm Hg, PaO2 48 mm Hg on room air. What is the main problem?
rationale_correct: Normal pH and PaCO2 indicate adequate ventilation. Low PaO2 reflects oxygenation impairment.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct physiologic separation. | B: CO2 normal. | C: HCO3- not provided but pH normal. | D: PaO2 clearly abnormal.
